waterbot.query: Is my tap water safe to drink? How do I know?
waterbot.expected_coverage: Check Consumer Confidence Report; public systems must meet MCLs; testing available

top_results.content: Chlorine smell = your water is being disinfected. This is good! The amount used is regulated and safe. If the taste bothers you, a simple carbon filter or leaving water in the fridge overnight will solve it.
Most cloudy water is just trapped air—completely harmless and clears within minutes. If your water doesn't clear, or if you notice color, odor, or particles, contact your water utility for guidance.
If you're healthy, drinking hard water is completely safe. If you dislike the effects on your home or skin, water softening is an option—but it's about comfort, not health.

waterbot.query: What is SB 606 and how does it affect my water usage?
waterbot.expected_coverage: AB 1668/SB 606 Making Conservation a Way of Life; permanent water use standards; supplier water budgets

top_results.content: AB 1668 and SB 606 shifted California from "save water during droughts" to "use water efficiently all the time." Your water supplier now has a permanent, customized efficiency budget — and real consequences for missing it.
- Performance measures for CII water uses

SB 1157 set a clear trajectory: Californians should use no more than 47 gallons per person per day indoors as of 2025, trending lower by 2030. This standard helps your water supplier build a realistic water budget — and gives them reason to offer you tools and incentives to save.

waterbot.query: How much water am I allowed to use per day in California?
waterbot.expected_coverage: Indoor standard is 47 GPCD as of 2025; standards apply to suppliers not individuals; outdoor varies by climate

top_results.content: SB 1157 set a clear trajectory: Californians should use no more than 47 gallons per person per day indoors as of 2025, trending lower by 2030. This standard helps your water supplier build a realistic water budget — and gives them reason to offer you tools and incentives to save.
- CalWEP (California Water Efficiency Partnership) guidance

Conservation standards will likely nudge your water rates up over time, but rebates, incentives, and smarter water use can more than offset the cost. Start by checking SaveOurWater.com for rebates in your area, fix any leaks, and make sure your landscape isn't drinking more water than it needs.

waterbot.query: What was the 20 by 2020 water conservation goal?
waterbot.expected_coverage: SB X7-7 Water Conservation Act of 2009; 20% reduction by 2020; achieved 32% reduction; 199 to 136 GPCD

top_results.content: - Population figures from Health and Safety Code Section 116530 reporting
- Total statewide annual losses: ~316,000 acre-feet

The efficiency standards create a comprehensive, progressively tighter framework through 2040. Indoor use shrinks to 47+ GPCD, outdoor landscaping must match 55-80% of plant needs, system leaks face economic-model-based limits, and commercial landscapes get their own declining budget.

waterbot.expected_coverage: Emergency vs permanent framework; drought restrictions are temporary; AB 1668/SB 606 standards are permanent

top_results.content: - Protects individual property owners during mandated conservation
- Target: ~20% supply shortage response
- Watering drought-sensitive vegetation during declared emergencies

waterbot.query: When does California start enforcing water use limits?
waterbot.expected_coverage: Regulation effective Jan 2025; graduated enforcement; penalties start Nov 2027; $1000-$10000 per day

top_results.content: AB 1668 and SB 606 shifted California from "save water during droughts" to "use water efficiently all the time." Your water supplier now has a permanent, customized efficiency budget — and real consequences for missing it.
Available beginning November 1, 2027 for suppliers not meeting objectives despite earlier enforcement actions.

California moved from "conserve only when the Governor says so" to "conserve all the time, with extra measures during emergencies." The permanent standards under AB 1668/SB 606 are now the baseline, and drought declarations can add temporary restrictions on top.

waterbot.query: What rebates are available for water-saving appliances in California?
waterbot.expected_coverage: Toilet, washer, showerhead rebates; turf removal; smart controllers; SaveOurWater.com rebate finder

top_results.content: Conservation standards will likely nudge your water rates up over time, but rebates, incentives, and smarter water use can more than offset the cost. Start by checking SaveOurWater.com for rebates in your area, fix any leaks, and make sure your landscape isn't drinking more water than it needs.

Save Our Water is your free, one-stop resource for saving water in California. Start with the rebate finder to see what incentives are available in your area, and explore the tips and tools to make conservation a part of your daily routine.
